Subject Granular Differential Privacy in Federated Learning

Virendra J. Marathe virendra.marathe@oracle.com Oracle Labs ,  Pallika Kanani pallika.kanani@oracle.com Oracle Labs ,  Daniel Peterson daniel.peterson@oracle.com Oracle Labs  and  Guy Steele Jr guy.steele@oracle.com Oracle Labs
Abstract.

This paper considers subject level privacy in the FL setting, where a subject is an individual whose private information is embodied by several data items either confined within a single federation user or distributed across multiple federation users. We propose two new algorithms that enforce subject level DP at each federation user locally. Our first algorithm, called \localgroupdp, is a straightforward application of group differential privacy in the popular DP-SGD algorithm. Our second algorithm is based on a novel idea of hierarchical gradient averaging (\higradavg) for subjects participating in a training mini-batch. We also show that user level Local Differential Privacy (LDP) naturally guarantees subject level DP. We observe the problem of horizontal composition of subject level privacy loss in FL – subject level privacy loss incurred at individual users composes across the federation. We formally prove the subject level DP guarantee for our algorithms, and also show their effect on model utility loss. Our empirical evaluation on FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets shows that \localgroupdp delivers the best performance among our algorithms. However, its model utility lags behind that of models trained using a DP-SGD based algorithm that provides a weaker item level privacy guarantee. Privacy loss amplification due to subject sampling fractions and horizontal composition remain key challenges for model utility.

††copyright: none

1. Introduction

Data privacy enforcement, using Differential Privacy (DP) (Dwork et al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014), in the Federated Learning (FL) setting (Konecný et al.,, 2015) has been explored at two granularities: (i) item level privacy, where use of each data item in model training is obfuscated (Abadi et al.,, 2016); and (ii) user level privacy, where participation of each federation user is hidden (McMahan et al.,, 2018).

Another dimension of DP in FL relates to the locale (physical location) of DP enforcement. The most common alternatives are (i) locally at federation users (Abadi et al.,, 2016; Differential Privacy Team,, 2017; Truex et al.,, 2020), and (ii) centrally at the federation server (McMahan et al.,, 2018). The privacy enforcement locale is dictated by assumptions made about the trust model between federation users and the server. A trusted server enables central enforcement of DP at the server, whereas the users may prefer to locally enforce DP with an untrusted server.

In this paper, we assume that the federation users and the server behave as honest-but-curious participants in the federation: They do not interfere with or manipulate the distributed training protocol, but may be interested in analyzing received model updates. Federation users do not trust each other or the federation server, and must locally enforce privacy guarantees for their private data.

User level privacy is perhaps the right privacy granularity in the original cross-device FL setting consisting millions of hand held devices (Bonawitz et al.,, 2019; Konecný et al.,, 2015). Furthermore, central enforcement of user level privacy (McMahan et al.,, 2018) appears to be the most viable approach in that setting. However, the cross-silo FL setting (Kairouz et al.,, 2019), where federation users are organizations that are themselves gatekeepers of data items of numerous individuals (which we call “subjects” henceforth), offer much richer mappings between subjects and their personal data.

In the simplest of use cases, a subject is embodied by a single data item across the entire federation. Thus item level privacy is sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy. However, many real world use cases exhibit more complex subject to data mappings. Consider a patient P𝑃P visiting different hospitals for treatment of different ailments. Each hospital contains multiple data records forming P𝑃P’s health history. These hospitals may decide to participate in a federation that uses their respective patients’ health history records in their training datasets. Thus distinct health history records of the same data subject (e.g. P𝑃P) can appear in the datasets of multiple hospitals. In the end, it is the privacy of these subjects that we want to preserve in a FL federation.

Item level privacy, irrespective of its enforcement locale, does not suffice to protect privacy of P𝑃P’s data. That is because item level privacy simply obfuscates participation of individual data items in the training process (Abadi et al.,, 2016; Dwork et al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014). Since a subject may have multiple data items in the dataset, item level private training may still leak a subject’s data distribution (Liu et al.,, 2020; McMahan et al.,, 2018). User level privacy enforced centrally (McMahan et al.,, 2018) does not protect the privacy of P𝑃P’s data either. User level privacy obfuscates each user’s participation in training (McMahan et al.,, 2018). However, a subject’s data can be distributed among several users, and it can be leaked when aggregated through FL. In the worst case, multiple federation users may host only the data of a single subject. Thus P𝑃P’s data distribution can be leaked even if individual users’ participation is obfuscated centrally.

In this paper, we consider a third granularity of privacy – subject level privacy (Wang et al.,, 2021)111 Wang et al. (Wang et al.,, 2021) identify what we call subjects in this paper as users in their paper., where a subject is an individual whose private data is spread across multiple data items, which can themselves be distributed across multiple federation users. The notion of subject level privacy is not new, and in fact appears in some of the original work on DP (Dwork et al.,, 2006; Dwork & Roth,, 2014). However, most existing work has either assumed a 111-to-111 mapping between subjects and data items (Abadi et al.,, 2016), or has treated subjects as individual silos of data (a.k.a. users) in a collaborative learning setting such as FL (McMahan et al.,, 2018). Recent work has addressed subject level privacy in a centralized setting (Levy et al.,, 2021), but no prior work has addressed the problem in a distributed collaborative learning setting such as FL. To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first study of subject level privacy in FL.

We formulate subject level privacy in terms of the classic definition of differential privacy (Dwork et al.,, 2006). We present two novel algorithms – \localgroupdp and \higradavg– that achieve subject level DP in the FL setting. We formally prove our algorithms’ subject level DP guarantee. We also show that user level Local Differential Privacy (LDP), called UserLDP, provides the subject level DP guarantee.

We observe that subject level privacy loss at individual federation users composes across users in the federation. We call this horizontal composition. We show that, in the worst case, horizontal composition is equivalent to composition of privacy loss in iterative computations such as ML model training over mini-batches. Consequently, the recent advances in adaptive composition results (Abadi et al.,, 2016; Dong et al.,, 2019; Dwork et al.,, 2010; Mironov,, 2017) apply to horizontal composition. This adds additional constraints on model training either in terms of additional noise injection or in terms of the amount of training permitted – reduction in training rounds by a factor of 1s1𝑠\frac{1}{\sqrt{s}}, where s𝑠s is the number of users sampled in a training round. These constraints adversely affect model utility.

We formally analyze utility loss of models trained with our algorithms in terms of excess population loss (Bassily et al.,, 2019, 2014), assuming L𝐿L-Lipschitz convex loss functions. We show that, compared to the utility loss incurred by the item level DP enforcement algorithm by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al.,, 2016) (LocalItemDP), utility loss of models trained using \localgroupdp, UserLDP, and \higradavg is affected significantly by different factors. In case of \localgroupdp and UserLDP, the utility degradation is amplified by a quadractic factor of the group size per mini-batch (the group size for UserLDP is the size of the mini-batch). For \higradavg, the utility degradation is amplified by a quadratic factor of the cardinality of the most frequently occuring subject in a federation user’s dataset.

Our empirical evaluation results, using the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets (Caldas et al.,, 2018), reflect our formal analysis of utility loss: \localgroupdp and UserLDP incur significant model utility overheads (degradation over LocalItemDP of 15%percent1515\% on FEMNIST and 18%percent1818\% on Shakespeare with \localgroupdp, and far worse with UserLDP). \higradavg leads to model degradation over LocalItemDP of 22%percent2222\% on FEMNIST, and much worse utility than even UserLDP on Shakespeare. This leaves us with the open problem of building high utility algorithms that guarantee subject level DP in FL.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Relevant definitions appear in Section 2. Our algorithms and horizontal composition are described in Section 3; we also prove their subject level DP guarantee. Section 4 formally shows the utility loss incurred more generally by subject level DP enforcement, and specifically by our algorithms. Our empirical evaluation appears in Section 5, followed by conclusion in Section 6.

2. Subject Level Differential Privacy

We begin with the definition of Differential Privacy (Dwork et al.,, 2006). Informally, DP bounds the maximum impact a single data item can have on the output of a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Formally,

Definition 2.1.

A randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒟→ℛ:𝒜→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is said to be (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-differentially private if for any two adjacent datasets D𝐷D, D′∈𝒟superscript𝐷′𝒟D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D}, and set S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

(1) Pr​[𝒜​(D)∈S]≤eε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+δPrdelimited-[]𝒜𝐷𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D)\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+\delta

where D𝐷D, D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are adjacent to each other if they differ from each other by a single data item. δ𝛿\delta is the probability of failure to enforce the ε𝜀\varepsilon privacy loss bound.

The above definition provides item level privacy. McMahan et al. (McMahan et al.,, 2018) present an alternate definition for user level DP in the FL setting. Let U𝑈U be the set of n𝑛n users participating in a federation, and 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} be the dataset of user ui∈Usubscript𝑢𝑖𝑈u_{i}\in U. Let 𝒟U=⋃i=1n𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{U}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{D}_{i}. Let ℛℛ\mathcal{R} be the range of models resulting from the FL training process.

Definition 2.2.

Given a FL training algorithm 𝒜:𝒟𝒰→ℛ:𝒜→subscript𝒟𝒰ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D_{U}}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}, we say that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is user level (ε,δ𝜀𝛿\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private if for any two adjacent user sets U𝑈U, U′⊆𝒰superscript𝑈′𝒰U^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{U}, and S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

(2) Pr​[𝒜​(𝒟U)∈S]≤eε​Pr​[𝒜​(𝒟U′)∈S]+δPrdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝒟𝑈𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝒟superscript𝑈′𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{U})\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{U^{\prime}})\in S]+\delta

where U𝑈U, U′superscript𝑈′U^{\prime} are adjacent user sets differing by a single user.

Let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} be the set of subjects whose data is hosted by the federation’s users U𝑈U. Our definition of subject level DP is based on the observation that, even though the data of individual subjects s∈𝒬𝑠𝒬s\in\mathcal{Q} may be physically scattered across multiple users in U𝑈U, the aggregate data across U𝑈U can be logically divided into its subjects in 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} (i.e. 𝒟U=⋃s∈𝒬𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑈subscript𝑠𝒬subscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{U}=\bigcup_{s\in\mathcal{Q}}\mathcal{D}_{s}).

Definition 2.3.

Given a FL training algorithm 𝒜:𝒟𝒰→ℛ:𝒜→subscript𝒟𝒰ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D_{U}}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}, we say that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is subject level (ε,δ𝜀𝛿\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private if for any two adjacent subject sets Q𝑄Q, Q′⊆𝒬superscript𝑄′𝒬Q^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{Q}, and S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

(3) Pr​[𝒜​(𝒟Q)∈S]≤eε​Pr​[𝒜​(𝒟Q′)∈S]+δPrdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝒟𝑄𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝒟superscript𝑄′𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{Q})\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{Q^{\prime}})\in S]+\delta

where Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime} are adjacent subject sets if they differ from each other by at most a single subject.

Note that the above definition completely ignores the notion of users in a federation. This user obliviousness is crucial to make the definition work for both cases: (i) where a subject’s data items are confined to a single user (e.g. for cross-device FL settings), and (ii) where a subject’s data items are spread across multiple users (e.g. for cross-silo FL settings) (Wang et al.,, 2021).

3. Enforcing Subject Level Differential Privacy

We assume a federation that contains a federation server that is responsible for (i) initialization and distribution of the model architecture to the federation users, (ii) coordination of training rounds, (iii) aggregation and application of model updates coming from different users in each training round, and (iv) redistribution of the updated model back to the users. Each federation user (i) receives updated models from the federation server, (ii) retrains the received models using its private training data, and (iii) returns updated model parameters to the federation server.

Our algorithms enforce subject level DP locally at each user. But to prove the privacy guarantee for any subject, across the entire federation, we must ensure that the local subject level DP guarantee composes correctly through the global aggregation, at the federation server, of parameter updates received from these users. To that end we break down the federated training round into two functions: (i) ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l}, the user’s training algorithm that enforces subject level DP locally, and (ii) ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g}, the server’s operation that aggregates parameter updates received from all the users. We first present our algorithms for ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} and show that they locally enforce subject level DP. Thereafter we show how an instance of ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} that simply averages parameter updates (at the federation server) composes the subject level DP guarantee across multiple users in the federation.

Our algorithms are based on a federated version of the DP-SGD algorithm by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al.,, 2016). DP-SGD was originially not designed for FL, but can be easily extended to enforce item level DP in FL: The federation server samples a random set of users for each training round and sends them a request to perform local training. Each user trains the model locally using DP-SGD. Formally, the parameter update at step t𝑡t in DP-SGD using a mini-batch of size b𝑏b can be summarized in the following equation:

(4) Θt=Θt−1+ηb​(∑i=1b▽​ℒiC​(Θt−1)+𝒩​(0,C2​σ2))subscriptΘ𝑡subscriptΘ𝑡1𝜂𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑏▽superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝐶subscriptΘ𝑡1𝒩0superscript𝐶2superscript𝜎2\Theta_{t}=\Theta_{t-1}+\frac{\eta}{b}(\sum_{i=1}^{b}\mathcal{\triangledown L}_{i}^{C}(\Theta_{t-1})+\mathcal{N}(0,C^{2}\sigma^{2}))

where, ▽​ℒiC▽superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝐶\mathcal{\triangledown L}_{i}^{C} is the loss function’s gradient, for data item i𝑖i in the mini-batch, clipped by the norm threshold of C𝐶C, σ𝜎\sigma is the noise scale calculated using the moments accountant method, 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} is the Gaussian distribution used to calculate noise, and η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. Note that the gradient for each data item is clipped separately to limit the influence (sensitivity) of each data item in the mini-batch. The σ𝜎\sigma is derived from Theorem 1 in (Abadi et al.,, 2016)

Theorem 3.1.

There exist constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} such that given the sampling probability q=B|D|𝑞𝐵𝐷q=\frac{B}{|D|}, where B𝐵B is the mini-batch size, D𝐷D the training dataset, and T𝑇T is the number of steps, for any ε<c1​q2​T𝜀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑞2𝑇\varepsilon<c_{1}q^{2}T, DP-SGD enforces item level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-differential privacy for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 if we choose

σ≥c2​q​T​l​o​g​(1/δ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑞𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{q\sqrt{Tlog(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}

The users ship back updated model parameters to the federation server, which averages the updates received from all the sampled users. The server redistributes the updated model and triggers another training round if needed. The original paper (Abadi et al.,, 2016) also proposed the moments accountant method for tighter composition of privacy loss bounds compared to prior work on strong composition (Dwork et al.,, 2010). We call this described algorithm LocalItemDP.

3.1. Locally Enforced Group Level Differential Privacy

Intuitively, LocalItemDP enforces item level DP by injecting noise proportional to any sampled data item’s influence in each mini-batch. In order to extend this approach to enforce subject level DP, we need to precisely calibrate noise proportional to a data subject’s influence on a mini-batch’s gradients. A direct method to attain that is by obfuscating the effects of the group of data items belonging to the same subject. We can apply the formalism of group differential privacy to achieve this group level obfuscation. The following theorem is a restatement, in our notation, of Theorem 2.22.22.2 and the associated footnote 111 from Dwork and Roth (Dwork & Roth,, 2014), §2.3:

Theorem 3.2.

Any (ε,δ𝜀𝛿\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒟→ℛ:𝒜→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is (k​ε,k​e(k−1)​ε​δ𝑘𝜀𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿k\varepsilon,ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private for groups of size k≥2𝑘2k\geq 2. That is, for all D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} such that D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differ in at most k𝑘k data items, and for all S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

Pr​[𝒜​(D)∈S]Prdelimited-[]𝒜𝐷𝑆\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D)\in S] ≤\displaystyle\leq ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+k​e(k−1)​ε​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿\displaystyle e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta

The proof of Theorem 3.2 appears in the appendix. The following definition is a direct consequence.

Definition 3.3.

We say that a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is (ℰ,ΔℰΔ\mathcal{E},\Delta)-group differentially private for a group size of g𝑔g, if 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is (ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-differentially private, where ℰ=g​ϵℰ𝑔italic-ϵ\mathcal{E}=g\epsilon, and Δ=g​e(g−1)​ϵΔ𝑔superscript𝑒𝑔1italic-ϵ\Delta=ge^{(g-1)\epsilon}.

Clearly, group DP incurs a big linear penalty on the privacy loss ε𝜀\varepsilon, and an even bigger penalty in the failure probability (g​e(g−1)​ε​δ𝑔superscript𝑒𝑔1𝜀𝛿ge^{(g-1)\varepsilon}\delta). Nevertheless, if g𝑔g is restricted to a small value (e.g. 222) the group DP penalty may be acceptable.

In the FL setting, subject level DP immediately follows from group DP for every sampled mini-batch of data items at every federation user. Let ℬℬ\mathcal{B} be a sampled mini-batch of data items at a user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and ℛℛ\mathcal{R} be the domain space of the ML model being trained in the FL setting.

Theorem 3.4.

Let training algorithm 𝒜g:ℬ→ℛ:subscript𝒜𝑔→ℬℛ\mathcal{A}_{g}:\mathcal{B}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} be group differentially private for groups of size g𝑔g, and l𝑙l be the largest number of data items belonging to any single subject in ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. If l≤g𝑙𝑔l\leq g, then 𝒜gsubscript𝒜𝑔\mathcal{A}_{g} is subject level differentially private.

Composition of group DP guarantees over multiple mini-batches and training rounds also follows established DP composition results (Abadi et al.,, 2016; Dwork et al.,, 2010; Mironov,, 2017). For instance, the moments accountant method by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al.,, 2016) shows that given an (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-DP gradient computation for a single mini-batch, the full training algorithm, which consists of T𝑇T mini-batches and a mini-batch sampling fraction of q𝑞q, is (O​(q​ε​T),δ)𝑂𝑞𝜀𝑇𝛿(O(q\varepsilon\sqrt{T}),\delta)-differentially private. Theorem 3.2 implies that the same algorithm is (O(gqεT,ge(g−1)​εδ)(O(gq\varepsilon\sqrt{T},ge^{(g-1)\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private for a group of size g𝑔g.

We now present our new FL training algorithm, \localgroupdp, that guarantees group DP. We make a critical assumption in \localgroupdp: Each user can determine the subject for any of its data items. Absent this assumption, the user may need to make the worst case assumption that all data items used to train the model belong to the same subject. On the other hand, these algorithms are strictly local, and do not require that the identity of the subjects be resolved across users.

\localgroupdp

( Algorithm 1) enforces subject level privacy locally at each user. Like prior work (Abadi et al.,, 2016; McMahan et al.,, 2018; Song et al.,, 2013), we enforce DP in \localgroupdp by adding carefully calibrated Gaussian noise in each mini-batch’s gradients. Each user clips gradients for each data item in a mini-batch to a clipping threshold C𝐶C prescribed by the federation server. The clipped gradients are subsequently averaged over the mini-batch. The clipping step bounds the sensitivity of each mini-batch’s gradients to C𝐶C.

To enforce group DP, \localgroupdp also locally tracks the item count of the subject with the largest number of items in the sampled mini-batch (LrgGrpCnt(ℬℬ\mathcal{B}) in Algorithm 1). This count determines the group size needed to enforce group DP for that mini-batch. This group size, Z𝑍Z in Algorithm 1, helps determine the noise scale σZsubscript𝜎𝑍\sigma_{Z}, given the target privacy parameters (ℰ,Δ)ℰΔ(\mathcal{E},\Delta) over the entire training round. More specifically, we use the moments accountant method and Definition 3.3 to calculate σZsubscript𝜎𝑍\sigma_{Z} for ε=ℰ/Z𝜀ℰ𝑍\varepsilon=\mathcal{E}/Z, and δ=Δ/(Z​e(Z−1)​ℰZ)𝛿Δ𝑍superscript𝑒𝑍1ℰ𝑍\delta=\Delta/(Ze^{(Z-1)\frac{\mathcal{E}}{Z}}). σZsubscript𝜎𝑍\sigma_{Z} is computed using the moments accountant method. The rest of the parameters to calculate σZsubscript𝜎𝑍\sigma_{Z} – ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, ΔΔ\Delta, total number of mini-batches (T.Rformulae-sequence𝑇𝑅T.R), and sampling fraction (B/t​o​t​a​l​d​a​t​a​s​e​t​s​i​z​e𝐵𝑡𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑠𝑒𝑡𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒B/total\ dataset\ size) – remain the same throughout the training process. \localgroupdp enforces (ℰ/Z,Δ/(Z​e(Z−1)​ℰZ)ℰ𝑍Δ𝑍superscript𝑒𝑍1ℰ𝑍\mathcal{E}/Z,\Delta/(Ze^{(Z-1)\frac{\mathcal{E}}{Z}})-differential privacy, which by Definition 3.3 implies (ℰℰ\mathcal{E},ΔΔ\Delta)-group differential privacy, hence subject level DP by Theorem 3.4.

3.2. Hierarchical Gradient Averaging

While \localgroupdp may seem like a reasonable approach to enforce subject level DP, its utility penalty due to group DP can be significant. For instance, even a group of size 222 effectively halves the available privacy budget ℰℰ\mathcal{E} for training. The key challenge to enforce subject level DP is that the following constraint seems fundamental: To guarantee subject level DP, any training algorithm must obfuscate the entire contribution made by any subject in the model’s parameter updates. \localgroupdp complies with this constraint by enforcing group DP.

Our new algorithm, called \higradavg (Algorithm 2), takes a diametrically opposite view to comply with the same constraint: Instead of scaling the noise to a subject’s group size (as is done in \localgroupdp), \higradavg scales down each subject’s mini-batch gradient contribution to the clipping threshold C𝐶C. This is done in three steps: (i) collect data items belonging to a common subject in the sampled mini-batch, (ii) compute and clip gradients using the threshold C𝐶C for each individual data item of the subject, and (iii) average those clipped gradients for the subject, denoted by gasubscript𝑔𝑎g_{a}. Clipping and then averaging gradients ensures that the entire subject’s gradient norm is bounded by C𝐶C.

Subsequently, \higradavg sums all the per-subject averaged gradients along with the Gaussian noise, which are then averaged over the number of distinct subjects |s​u​b​j​e​c​t​s​(S)|𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑗𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑠𝑆|subjects(S)| sampled in the mini-batch S𝑆S. \higradavg gets its name from this average-of-averages step. These two averaging steps have the result of mapping each subject a𝑎a’s data items’ gradients to a single representative averaged gradient for a𝑎a in the mini-batch S𝑆S.

The Gaussian noise scale σ𝜎\sigma is calculated independently at each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} using standard parameters – the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon, the failure probability δ𝛿\delta and total number of mini-batches T.Rformulae-sequence𝑇𝑅T.R over the entire multi-round training process. For the sampling fraction, we must consider sampling probability of individual subjects instead of data items. As a result, the subject sampling fraction becomes q=k​B|Di|𝑞𝑘𝐵subscript𝐷𝑖q=\frac{kB}{|D_{i}|}, where k𝑘k is the maximum number of data items belonging to any subject a∈s​u​b​j​e​c​t​s​(ℬ)𝑎𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑗𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑠ℬa\in subjects(\mathcal{B}) in the dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Composition of the privacy loss is done using the moments accountant method (Abadi et al.,, 2016).

To formally prove that \higradavg enforces subject level DP, we first provide a formal definition of subject sensitivity in a sampled mini-batch.

Definition 3.5 (Subject Sensitivity).

Given a model ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, and a sampled mini-batch ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of training data, we define subject sensitivity 𝕊ℬsuperscript𝕊ℬ\mathbb{S}^{\mathcal{B}} of ℬℬ\mathcal{B} as the upper bound on the gradient norm of any single subject a∈s​u​b​j​e​c​t​s​(ℬ)𝑎𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑗𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑠ℬa\in subjects(\mathcal{B}).

The per-subject averaging of clipped gradients gasubscript𝑔𝑎g_{a} results in the following lemma

Lemma 3.6.

For every sampled mini-batch ℬℬ\mathcal{B} in a sampled user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}’s training round in \higradavg, the subject sensitivity 𝕊ℬsuperscript𝕊ℬ\mathbb{S}^{\mathcal{B}} for ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is bounded by C𝐶C; i.e. 𝕊ℬ≤|C|superscript𝕊ℬ𝐶\mathbb{S}^{\mathcal{B}}\leq|C|.

Scaling the Gaussian noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma by a factor of |C|𝐶|C| ensures that the noise matches any subject’s signal in each mini-batch. Furthermore, σ𝜎\sigma itself is derived, based on Theorem 3.1, from

Theorem 3.7.

There exist constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} such that given the subject sampling probability q=k​B|Di|𝑞𝑘𝐵subscript𝐷𝑖q=\frac{kB}{|D_{i}|}, where k𝑘k is the expected number of data items per subject in dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}, and number of steps T𝑇T, for any ε<c1​k2​q2​T𝜀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑘2superscript𝑞2𝑇\varepsilon<c_{1}k^{2}q^{2}T, \higradavg enforces subject level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-differential privacy for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 if we choose

σ≥c2​k​q​T​l​o​g​(1/δ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑘𝑞𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{kq\sqrt{Tlog(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}

The proof for Theorem 3.7 follows the proof for Theorem 1 in (Abadi et al.,, 2016) albeit by changing the sampling probability from q=B|Di|𝑞𝐵subscript𝐷𝑖q=\frac{B}{|D_{i}|} to q=k​B|Di|𝑞𝑘𝐵subscript𝐷𝑖q=\frac{kB}{|D_{i}|}. The sampling probability’s scaling factor p𝑝p captures sampling of data subjects instead of data items. As a result, the noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma scales up by a factor of p𝑝p for subject level DP as compared to item level DP in (Abadi et al.,, 2016).

3.3. User Level Local Differential Privacy

While centrally enforced user level privacy (McMahan et al.,, 2018) is not sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy, we observe that Local Differential Privacy (LDP) (Duchi et al.,, 2013; Kasiviswanathan et al.,, 2008; Warner,, 1965) is sufficient to guarantee subject level privacy. There are strong parallels between the traditional LDP setting, where a data analyst can get access to the data only after it has been perturbed, and privacy in the FL setting, where the federation server gets access to parameter updates from users after they have been locally perturbed by the users. In fact, LDP obfuscates the entire signal from a user to the extent that an adversary, even the federation server, cannot tell the difference between the signals coming from any two different users.

Definition 3.8.

We say that FL algorithm 𝒜:𝒟𝒰→ℛ:𝒜→subscript𝒟𝒰ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D_{U}}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is user level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-locally differentially private, where 𝒟𝒰subscript𝒟𝒰\mathcal{D_{U}} is the dataset domain of users in set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}, and ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is the model parameter domain, if for any two users u1,u2∈𝒰subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2𝒰u_{1},u_{2}\in\mathcal{U}, and S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

(5) Pr​[𝒜​(Du1)∈S]≤eε​Pr​[𝒜​(Du2)∈S]+δPrdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷subscript𝑢1𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷subscript𝑢2𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{u_{1}})\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{u_{2}})\in S]+\delta

where Du1subscript𝐷subscript𝑢1D_{u_{1}} and Du2subscript𝐷subscript𝑢2D_{u_{2}} are the datasets of users u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} respectively.

We now present a new user level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-LDP algorithm called UserLDP. The underlying intuition behind this algorithm is to let the user locally inject enough noise to make its entire signal indistinguishable from any other user’s signal. In every training round, each federation user enforces user level LDP independently of the federation and any other users in the federation. The federation server simply averages parameter updates received from users and broadcasts the new averaged parameters back to the users.

UserLDP’s pseudo code appears in Algorithm 3. Note that UserLDP appears very similar to DP-SGD (Abadi et al.,, 2016). However, there are two significant differences between the two algorithms: First, while DP-SGD scales the noise proportional to the gradient contribution of any single data item in a mini-batch, UserLDP computes noise proportional to the gradient contribution of the entire mini-batch (line 999). To guarantee DP, we need to first cap the sensitivity of each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}’s contribution to parameter updates. To that end, we focus on change affected by any mini-batch ℬℬ\mathcal{B} trained at uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. Line 777 in Algorithm 3 ensures the following lemma.

Lemma 3.9.

For every mini-batch ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of a sampled user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}’s training round in UserLDP, the sensitivity 𝕊ℬsubscript𝕊ℬ\mathbb{S}_{\mathcal{B}} of the computed parameter gradient is bounded by C𝐶C; i.e. 𝕊ℬ≤|C|subscript𝕊ℬ𝐶\mathbb{S}_{\mathcal{B}}\leq|C|.

Second, since we are interested in enforcing user level LDP, the sampling probability of the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} for each of its mini-batches is q=1𝑞1q=1. Thus the Gaussian noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma is derived, again based on Theorem 3.1, from

Theorem 3.10.

There exist constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} such that given the number of steps T𝑇T, for any ε<c1​T𝜀subscript𝑐1𝑇\varepsilon<c_{1}T, UserLDP enforces user level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-differential privacy for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 if we choose

σ≥c2​T​l​o​g​(1/δ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{\sqrt{Tlog(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}

Sampling probability of q=1𝑞1q=1 precludes privacy amplification by sampling (Abadi et al.,, 2016; Bassily et al.,, 2014; Kasiviswanathan et al.,, 2008; Wang et al.,, 2019), which significantly degrades the trained model’s utility.

For any sampled user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, assume w.l.o.g. that uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} trains for T𝑇T mini-batches in a single training round. Thus the aggregate sensitivity of parameter updates over a training round (T𝑇T mini-batches) for uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} is bounded by η​T​C𝜂𝑇𝐶\eta TC, where η𝜂\eta is the mini-batch learning rate. Thus the parameter update from uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, as observed by the federation server, is norm bounded by η​T​C𝜂𝑇𝐶\eta TC, and the cumulative noise from the distribution 𝒩(0,ηTσ2C2𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,\eta T\sigma^{2}C^{2}{\bf I}) (by linear composition of Gaussian distributions). More precisely, let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be the change in parameters affected by any user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. Then

(6) ||𝒞(ui)||2≤η(|TC|+|𝒩(0,Tσ2C2𝐈|)||\mathcal{C}(u_{i})||_{2}\leq\eta(|TC|+|\mathcal{N}(0,T\sigma^{2}C^{2}{\bf I}|)

Lemma 3.9 and Theorem 3.10 ensure that the parameter update signal for the entire training round at uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} is matched with correctly calibrated Gaussian noise forming a locally randomized response (Kasiviswanathan et al.,, 2008; Warner,, 1965) that is shared with the federation server.

Theorem 3.11.

UserLDP with parameter updates satisfying Equation 6 as observed by the federation server in a training round, enforces user level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-local differential privacy provided the noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma satisfies the inequality from Theorem 3.10, and the following inequality

σ>12​π​ε​δ​eε𝜎12𝜋𝜀𝛿superscript𝑒𝜀\displaystyle\sigma>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}\varepsilon\delta e^{\varepsilon}}

Proof for Theorem 3.11 appears in the appendix.

3.4. Composition Over Multiple Training Rounds

Composition of privacy loss across multiple training rounds can be done by straightforward application of DP composition results, such as the moments accountant method that we use in our work. Thus the privacy loss εrsubscript𝜀𝑟\varepsilon_{r} incurred in any single training round r𝑟r amplifies by a factor of R𝑅\sqrt{R} when federated training runs for R𝑅R rounds. We note that privacy losses are incurred by federation users independently of other federation users. Foreknowledge of the number of training rounds R𝑅R lets us calculate the Gaussian noise distribution’s standard deviation σ𝜎\sigma for a privacy loss budget of (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta) for the aggregate training over R𝑅R rounds. Given an aggregate privacy loss budget of ε𝜀\varepsilon, since all users train for an identical number of rounds R𝑅R, they incur a privacy loss of εr=εRsubscript𝜀𝑟𝜀𝑅\varepsilon_{r}=\frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{R}} in each training round r𝑟r. Notably, this privacy loss per training round is the the same for all users even if their dataset cardinalities are dramatically different.

3.5. Composing Subject Level DP Across Federation Users

At the beginning of a training round r𝑟r, each sampled user receives a copy of the global model, with parameters Θr−1subscriptΘ𝑟1\Theta_{r-1}, which it then retrains using its private data. Since all sampled users start retraining from the same model ℳΘr−1subscriptℳsubscriptΘ𝑟1\mathcal{M}_{\Theta_{r-1}}, and independently retrain the model using their respective private data, parallel composition of privacy loss across these sampled users may seem to apply naturally (McSherry,, 2009). In that case, the aggregate privacy loss incurred across multiple federation users, via an aggregation such as federated averaging, remains identical to the privacy loss εrsubscript𝜀𝑟\varepsilon_{r} incurred individually at each user. However, parallel composition was proposed for item level privacy, where an item belongs to at most one participant. With subject level privacy, a subject’s data items can span across multiple users, which limits application of parallel privacy loss composition to only those federations where each subject’s data is restricted to at most one federation user. In the more general case, we show that subject level privacy loss composes adaptively via the federated averaging aggregation algorithm used in our FL training algorithms.

Formally, consider a FL training algorithm ℱ=(ℱl,ℱg)ℱsubscriptℱ𝑙subscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), where ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} is the user local component, and ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} the global aggregation component of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. Given a federation user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, let ℱl:(ℳ,Dui)→θui:subscriptℱ𝑙→ℳsubscript𝐷subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝑢𝑖\mathcal{F}_{l}:(\mathcal{M},D_{u_{i}})\rightarrow\theta_{u_{i}}, where ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is a model, Duisubscript𝐷subscript𝑢𝑖D_{u_{i}} is the private dataset of user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and θuisubscript𝜃subscript𝑢𝑖\theta_{u_{i}} is the updated parameters produced by ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l}. Let ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} be 1n​∑iθui1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝑢𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\theta_{u_{i}}, a parameter update averaging algorithm over a set of n𝑛n federation users uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}.

Theorem 3.12.

Given a FL training algorithm ℱ=(ℱl,ℱg)ℱsubscriptℱ𝑙subscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), in the most general case where a subject’s data resides in the private datasets of multiple federation users uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, the aggregation algorithm ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} adaptively composes subject level privacy losses incurred by ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} at each federation user.

We term this composition of privacy loss across federation users as horizontal composition. Horizontal composition has a significant effect on the number of federated training rounds permitted under a given privacy loss budget.

Theorem 3.13.

Consider a FL training algorithm ℱ=(ℱl,ℱg)ℱsubscriptℱ𝑙subscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}) that samples s𝑠s users per training round, and trains the model ℳℳ\mathcal{M} for R𝑅R rounds. Let ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} at each participating user, over the aggregate of R𝑅R training rounds, locally enforce subject level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-DP. Then ℱℱ\mathcal{F} globally enforces the same subject level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-DP guarantee by training for Rs𝑅𝑠\frac{R}{\sqrt{s}} rounds.

The main intuition behind Theorem 3.13 is that the s𝑠s-way horizontal composition via ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} results in an increase in training mini-batches by a factor of s𝑠s. As a result, the privacy loss calculated by the moments accountant method amplifies by a factor of s𝑠\sqrt{s}, thereby forcing a reduction in number of training rounds by a factor of s𝑠\sqrt{s} to counteract the privacy loss amplification. This reduction in training rounds can have a significant impact on the resulting model’s performance, as we demonstrate in section 5. Proofs for Theorem 3.12 and Theorem 3.13 appear in the appendix.

An alternate approach to account for horizontal composition of privacy loss is to simply scale the number of training minibatches (called lots by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al.,, 2016)) by the number of federation users sampled in each training round. The scaled minibatch (lot) count can be used by each user to privately calculate the noise scale σ𝜎\sigma at the beginning of the entire federated training process. An increase in the number of total minibatches does lead to a significant increase in the noise introduced in each minibatch’s gradients, resulting in model performance degradation.

4. Utility Loss

Our utility loss formalism leverages a long line of former work on differentially private empirical risk minimization (ERM) (Bassily et al.,, 2019, 2014; Chaudhuri et al.,, 2011; Duchi et al.,, 2013; Iyengar et al.,, 2019; Kifer et al.,, 2012; Song et al.,, 2013; Talwar et al.,, 2015; Thakurta & Smith,, 2013; Wang et al.,, 2018). In particular, we extend the notation of, and heavily base our formal analysis on work by Bassily et al. (Bassily et al.,, 2019), applying it to subject level DP in general, with specializations for our individual algorithms.

Let 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} denote the data domain, and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} denote a data distribution over 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. We assume a L𝐿L-Lipschitz convex loss function ℓ:ℝd×𝒵→ℝ:ℓ→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒵ℝ\ell:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} that maps a parameter vector 𝐰∈W𝐰𝑊{\bf w}\in W, where W⊂ℝd𝑊superscriptℝ𝑑W\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is a convex parameter space, and a data point z∈𝒵𝑧𝒵z\in\mathcal{Z}, to a real value.

Definition 4.1 (α𝛼\alpha-Uniform Stability (Bassily et al.,, 2019; Bousquet & Elisseeff,, 2002)).

Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. A randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒵n→W:𝒜→superscript𝒵𝑛𝑊\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Z}^{n}\rightarrow W is α𝛼\alpha-uniformly stable (w.r.t. loss ℓ:W×𝒵→ℝ:ℓ→𝑊𝒵ℝ\ell:W\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}) if for any pair S,S′∈𝒵n𝑆superscript𝑆′superscript𝒵𝑛S,S^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Z}^{n} differing in at most one data point, we have

supz∈𝒵𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(S),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(S′),z)]≤αsubscriptsupremum𝑧𝒵𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜𝑆𝑧ℓ𝒜superscript𝑆′𝑧𝛼\displaystyle\sup_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S^{\prime}),z)]\leq\alpha
Definition 4.2 ((k,α)𝑘𝛼(k,\alpha)-Uniform Stability).

Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. A randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒵n→W:𝒜→superscript𝒵𝑛𝑊\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Z}^{n}\rightarrow W is said to be (k,α)𝑘𝛼(k,\alpha)-uniformly stable (w.r.t loss ℓ:W×𝒵→ℝ:ℓ→𝑊𝒵ℝ\ell:W\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}) if for any pair S,S′∈𝒵n𝑆superscript𝑆′superscript𝒵𝑛S,S^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Z}^{n} differing in at most k𝑘k data points, we have

supz∈𝒵𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(S),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(S′),z)]≤k​αsubscriptsupremum𝑧𝒵𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜𝑆𝑧ℓ𝒜superscript𝑆′𝑧𝑘𝛼\displaystyle\sup_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S^{\prime}),z)]\leq k\alpha

𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(Sk),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(S0),z)]≤β𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑘𝑧ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆0𝑧𝛽\displaystyle\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{k}),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{0}),z)]\leq\beta
Lemma 4.3.

A (randomized) algorithm 𝒜:𝒵n→W:𝒜→superscript𝒵𝑛𝑊\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Z}^{n}\rightarrow W is (k,βk)𝑘𝛽𝑘(k,\frac{\beta}{k})-uniformly stable iff it is βk𝛽𝑘\frac{\beta}{k}-uniformly stable.

By i.i.d. and symmetry assumptions, we get ∀i∈1,2,…,kfor-all𝑖12…𝑘\forall i\in{1,2,...,k}

For the other direction of the iff we use the same sets S0,S1,S2,…,Sksubscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2…subscript𝑆𝑘S_{0},S_{1},S_{2},...,S_{k}, and assume ∀i∈1,2,…,kfor-all𝑖12…𝑘\forall i\in{1,2,...,k}

𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(Si),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(Si−1),z)]≤βk𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖𝑧ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖1𝑧𝛽𝑘\displaystyle\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i}),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i-1}),z)]\leq\frac{\beta}{k}

Hence,

𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(Sk),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(S0),z)]𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑘𝑧ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆0𝑧\displaystyle\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{k}),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{0}),z)]
=𝔼𝒜​[∑i=1k(ℓ​(𝒜​(Si),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(Si−1),z))]absent𝒜𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖𝑧ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖1𝑧\displaystyle=\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\sum_{i=1}^{k}(\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i}),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i-1}),z))]
=∑i=1k𝔼𝒜​[ℓ​(𝒜​(Si),z)−ℓ​(𝒜​(Si−1),z)]absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖𝑧ℓ𝒜subscript𝑆𝑖1𝑧\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{k}\underset{\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i}),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}(S_{i-1}),z)]
≤βabsent𝛽\displaystyle\leq\beta

∎

4.1. General Utility Loss for Subject Level Privacy

Given the parameter vector 𝐰∈W𝐰𝑊{\bf w}\in W, dataset S=s1,s2,…,sn𝑆subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2…subscript𝑠𝑛S={s_{1},s_{2},...,s_{n}}, and loss function ℓℓ\ell, we define the empirical loss of 𝐰𝐰{\bf w} as ℒ^​(𝐰;S)≜1n​∑i=1nℓ​(𝐰,si)≜^ℒ𝐰𝑆1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛ℓ𝐰subscript𝑠𝑖\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)\triangleq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ell({\bf w},s_{i}), and the excess empirical loss of 𝐰𝐰{\bf w} as Δ​ℒ^​(𝐰;S)≜ℒ^​(𝐰;S)−m​i​n𝐰~∈W​ℒ^​(𝐰~;S)≜Δ^ℒ𝐰𝑆^ℒ𝐰𝑆~𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛^ℒ~𝐰𝑆\Delta\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)\triangleq\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)-\underset{\tilde{\bf w}\in W}{min}\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\tilde{\bf w};S). Similarly we define the population loss of 𝐰∈W𝐰𝑊{\bf w}\in W w.r.t. loss ℓℓ\ell and a distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} over 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} as ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟)≜𝔼z∼𝒟​[ℓ​(𝐰,z)]≜ℒ𝐰𝒟similar-to𝑧𝒟𝔼delimited-[]ℓ𝐰𝑧\mathcal{L}({\bf w};\mathcal{D})\triangleq\underset{z\sim\mathcal{D}}{\mathbb{E}}[\ell({\bf w},z)]. The excess population loss of 𝐰𝐰{\bf w} is defined as Δ​ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟)≜ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟)−m​i​n𝐰~∈W​ℒ​(𝐰~;𝒟)≜Δℒ𝐰𝒟ℒ𝐰𝒟~𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛ℒ~𝐰𝒟\Delta\mathcal{L}({\bf w};\mathcal{D})\triangleq\mathcal{L}({\bf w};\mathcal{D})-\underset{\tilde{\bf w}\in W}{min}\mathcal{L}(\tilde{\bf w};\mathcal{D}).

Lemma 4.4 (from (Bassily et al.,, 2019)).

Let 𝒜:𝒵n→W:𝒜→superscript𝒵𝑛𝑊\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Z}^{n}\rightarrow W be a βk𝛽𝑘\frac{\beta}{k}-uniformly stable algorithm w.r.t. loss ℓ:W×𝒵→ℝ:ℓ→𝑊𝒵ℝ\ell:W\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. Let 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} be any distribution over 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, and let S∼𝒟nsimilar-to𝑆superscript𝒟𝑛S\sim\mathcal{D}^{n}. Then,

(7) 𝔼S∼𝒟n,𝒜​[ℒ​(𝒜​(S);𝒟)−ℒ^​(𝒜​(S);S)]≤βksimilar-to𝑆superscript𝒟𝑛𝒜𝔼delimited-[]ℒ𝒜𝑆𝒟^ℒ𝒜𝑆𝑆𝛽𝑘\underset{S\sim\mathcal{D}^{n},\mathcal{A}}{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A}(S);\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\mathcal{A}(S);S)]\leq\frac{\beta}{k}

Let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be a L𝐿L-Lipschitz convex function that uses dataset S𝑆S to generate an approximate minimizer 𝐰^S∈Wsubscript^𝐰𝑆𝑊\hat{\bf w}_{S}\in W for ℒ(.;𝒟)\mathcal{L}(.;\mathcal{D}). Thus the accuracy of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is measured in terms of expected excess population loss

(8) Δ​ℒ​(𝒜;𝒟)≜𝔼​[ℒ​(𝐰^S;𝒟)−m​i​n𝐰∈W​ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟)]≜Δℒ𝒜𝒟𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript^𝐰𝑆𝒟𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛ℒ𝐰𝒟\Delta\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A};\mathcal{D})\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\hat{\bf w}_{S};\mathcal{D})-\underset{{\bf w}\in W}{min}\mathcal{L}({\bf w};\mathcal{D})]
Lemma 4.5.

Let 𝒜S​D​Psubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{SDP} be a L𝐿L-Lipschitz randomized algorithm that guarantees subject level (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP. Let T𝑇T be the number of training iterations, m𝑚m the minibatch size per training step, and η𝜂\eta the learning rate. Then, 𝒜S​D​Psubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{SDP} is (κ,α)𝜅𝛼(\kappa,\alpha)-uniformly stable, where κ𝜅\kappa is the expected number of data items for any subject spsubscript𝑠𝑝s_{p} appearing in 𝒜S​D​Psubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{SDP}’s training dataset, and α=L2​(T+1)​ηn𝛼superscript𝐿2𝑇1𝜂𝑛\alpha=L^{2}\frac{(T+1)\eta}{n}.

Proof.

Consider dataset S𝑆S comprising data items of nssubscript𝑛𝑠n_{s} subjects s1,…,sp−1,sp,sp+1,…,snssubscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝑝1subscript𝑠𝑝subscript𝑠𝑝1…subscript𝑠subscript𝑛𝑠s_{1},...,s_{p-1},s_{p},s_{p+1},...,s_{n_{s}}, and dataset S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} comprising data items of ns−1subscript𝑛𝑠1n_{s}-1 subjects s1,…,sp−1,sp+1,…,snssubscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝑝1subscript𝑠𝑝1…subscript𝑠subscript𝑛𝑠s_{1},...,s_{p-1},s_{p+1},...,s_{n_{s}}; i.e. S𝑆S and S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} differ from each other by a single data subject spsubscript𝑠𝑝s_{p}. Let number of data items per subject |si|>0subscript𝑠𝑖0|s_{i}|>0.

Let 𝐰0,𝐰1,…​𝐰Tsubscript𝐰0subscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑇{\bf w}_{0},{\bf w}_{1},...{\bf w}_{T} and 𝐰0′,𝐰1′,…,𝐰T′subscriptsuperscript𝐰′0subscriptsuperscript𝐰′1…subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑇{\bf w}^{\prime}_{0},{\bf w}^{\prime}_{1},...,{\bf w}^{\prime}_{T} be the parameter values of 𝒜S​D​Psubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{SDP} corresponding to T𝑇T training steps taken over input datasets S𝑆S and S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} respectively. Let ξt≜𝐰t−𝐰t′≜subscript𝜉𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑡\xi_{t}\triangleq{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf w}^{\prime}_{t} for any t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T].

Assume random sampling with replacement for a minibatch of data items. Let r𝑟r be the number of data items in a sampled minibatch of size m𝑚m that belong to subject spsubscript𝑠𝑝s_{p}. Then, by the non-expansiveness property of the gradient update step, we have

‖ξτ+1‖≤‖ξτ‖+2​L​η​rmnormsubscript𝜉𝜏1normsubscript𝜉𝜏2𝐿𝜂𝑟𝑚\displaystyle\|\xi_{\tau+1}\|\leq\|\xi_{\tau}\|+2L\eta\frac{r}{m}

Note that r𝑟r is a binomial random variable. Thus the expected value of r𝑟r, i.e. 𝔼​[r]=m​κn𝔼delimited-[]𝑟𝑚𝜅𝑛\mathbb{E}[r]=m\frac{\kappa}{n}, where κ=𝔼​[|sp|]𝜅𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑠𝑝\kappa=\mathbb{E}[|s_{p}|]. Thus κ𝜅\kappa depends on the underlying data distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. For instance, if 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is a uniform distribution, κ=nns𝜅𝑛subscript𝑛𝑠\kappa=\frac{n}{n_{s}}, where nssubscript𝑛𝑠n_{s} is the number subjects in S𝑆S. Assuming ‖ξ0‖=0normsubscript𝜉00\|\xi_{0}\|=0, taking expectation and using the induction hypothesis, we get

𝔼​[‖ξτ+1‖]𝔼delimited-[]normsubscript𝜉𝜏1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\xi_{\tau+1}\|] ≤2​L​η​(τ+1)​κnabsent2𝐿𝜂𝜏1𝜅𝑛\displaystyle\leq 2L\frac{\eta(\tau+1)\kappa}{n}
=2​L​η​(τ+1)​κnabsent2𝐿𝜂𝜏1𝜅𝑛\displaystyle=2L\frac{\eta(\tau+1)\kappa}{n}

Now let 𝐰¯T=∑t=1T𝐰tsubscript¯𝐰𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝐰𝑡\bar{\bf w}_{T}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}{\bf w}_{t} and 𝐰¯T′=∑t=1T𝐰t′subscriptsuperscript¯𝐰′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑡\bar{\bf w}^{\prime}_{T}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}{\bf w}^{\prime}_{t}. Since ℓℓ\ell is L𝐿L-Lipschitz, for every z∈𝒵𝑧𝒵z\in\mathcal{Z} we get

𝔼​[ℓ​(𝐰¯T,z)−ℓ​(𝐰¯T′,z)]𝔼delimited-[]ℓsubscript¯𝐰𝑇𝑧ℓsubscriptsuperscript¯𝐰′𝑇𝑧\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\ell(\bar{\bf w}_{T},z)-\ell(\bar{\bf w}^{\prime}_{T},z)] =𝔼​[ℓ​(𝒜S​D​P​(S),z)−ℓ​(𝒜S​D​P​(S′),z)]absent𝔼delimited-[]ℓsubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃𝑆𝑧ℓsubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃superscript𝑆′𝑧\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[\ell(\mathcal{A}_{SDP}(S),z)-\ell(\mathcal{A}_{SDP}(S^{\prime}),z)]
≤L.𝔼​[‖𝐰¯T−𝐰¯T′‖]formulae-sequenceabsent𝐿𝔼delimited-[]normsubscript¯𝐰𝑇subscriptsuperscript¯𝐰′𝑇\displaystyle\leq L.\mathbb{E}[\|\bar{\bf w}_{T}-\bar{\bf w}^{\prime}_{T}\|]
≤L​1T​∑t=1T𝔼​[‖ξt‖]absent𝐿1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼delimited-[]normsubscript𝜉𝑡\displaystyle\leq L\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}[\|\xi_{t}\|]
≤L​1T​2​L​η​κn​∑t=1Ttabsent𝐿1𝑇2𝐿𝜂𝜅𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝑡\displaystyle\leq L\frac{1}{T}\frac{2L\eta\kappa}{n}\sum_{t=1}^{T}t
=L2​(T+1)​η​κnabsentsuperscript𝐿2𝑇1𝜂𝜅𝑛\displaystyle=L^{2}\frac{(T+1)\eta\kappa}{n}

∎

Note that the above bound is a scaled version (by κ𝜅\kappa) of the recently shown bound for item level DP (Bassily et al.,, 2019). Thus, intuitively in our case, the smaller the number of data items per subject in a dataset, the closer our bound is to that of item level DP. Our bound is identical to the item level DP bound in the extreme case where each subject has just one data item in the dataset.

From Lemma 4.5,  Equation 7 and Equation 8, and substituting k=κ𝑘𝜅k=\kappa and β=L2​(T+1)​η​κn𝛽superscript𝐿2𝑇1𝜂𝜅𝑛\beta=L^{2}\frac{(T+1)\eta\kappa}{n} in Equation 7, we get

Theorem 4.6.

Let 𝒜S​D​Psubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{SDP} be a L𝐿L-Lipschitz randomized algorithm that guarantees subject level (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP. Then its excess population loss is bounded by

Δ​ℒ​(𝒜S​D​P;𝒟)≤Δℒsubscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃𝒟absent\displaystyle\Delta\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A}_{SDP};\mathcal{D})\leq
𝔼S∼𝒟n,𝒜S​D​P​[ℒ^​(𝐰¯T;S)−m​i​n𝐰∈W​ℒ^​(𝐰;S)]+L2​η​(T+1)nsimilar-to𝑆superscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝒜𝑆𝐷𝑃𝔼delimited-[]^ℒsubscript¯𝐰𝑇𝑆𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛^ℒ𝐰𝑆superscript𝐿2𝜂𝑇1𝑛\displaystyle\underset{S\sim\mathcal{D}^{n},\mathcal{A}_{SDP}}{\mathbb{E}}[\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{\bf w}_{T};S)-\underset{{\bf w}\in W}{min}\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)]+L^{2}\frac{\eta(T+1)}{n}

Interestingly, the above inequality appears to be identical to the excess population loss bound of work by Bassily et al. on item level DP (Bassily et al.,, 2019). However, only the third RHS term is identical, and the first two RHS terms evaluate to different quantities for all of our algorithms as we show below.

4.2. Utility Loss for \localgroupdp and UserLDP

We now formally show how \localgroupdp amplifies the Gaussian noise that factors directly into excess population loss Δ​ℒΔℒ\Delta\mathcal{L}.

Lemma 4.7.

Let W𝑊W be the M𝑀M-bounded convex parameter space for \localgroupdp, and S∈𝒵n𝑆superscript𝒵𝑛S\in\mathcal{Z}^{n} be the input (training) dataset. Let (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) be the subject level DP parameters for \localgroupdp, q𝑞q be the minibatch sampling ratio, and d𝑑d the model dimensionality. Then, for any η>0𝜂0\eta>0, the excess empirical loss of \localgroupdp is bounded by

𝔼​[ℒ^​(𝐰¯T;S)]−m​i​n𝐰∈W​ℒ^​(𝐰;S)≤𝔼delimited-[]^ℒsubscript¯𝐰𝑇𝑆𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛^ℒ𝐰𝑆absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{\bf w}_{T};S)]-\underset{{\bf w}\in W}{min}\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)\leq
M22​η​T+η​L22+η​d​c22​k2​q2ε2​(T​l​o​g​k​e(k−1)​ε/kδ)superscript𝑀22𝜂𝑇𝜂superscript𝐿22𝜂𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22superscript𝑘2superscript𝑞2superscript𝜀2𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝑘𝛿\displaystyle\frac{M^{2}}{2\eta T}+\frac{\eta L^{2}}{2}+\eta d\frac{c_{2}^{2}k^{2}q^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\left(Tlog\frac{ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon/k}}{\delta}\right)
Proof.

From the classic analysis of gradient descent on convex-Lipschitz functions (Bassily et al.,, 2019; Shalev-Shwartz & Ben-David,, 2014), we get

𝔼​[ℒ^​(𝐰¯T;S)]−m​i​n𝐰∈W​ℒ^​(𝐰;S)≤M22​η​T+η​L22+η​σ2​d𝔼delimited-[]^ℒsubscript¯𝐰𝑇𝑆𝐰𝑊𝑚𝑖𝑛^ℒ𝐰𝑆superscript𝑀22𝜂𝑇𝜂superscript𝐿22𝜂superscript𝜎2𝑑\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\hat{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{\bf w}_{T};S)]-\underset{{\bf w}\in W}{min}\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w};S)\leq\frac{M^{2}}{2\eta T}+\frac{\eta L^{2}}{2}+\eta\sigma^{2}d

where the last term on the RHS of the inequality is the additional empirical error due to that privacy enforcing noise.

By Theorem 111 from (Abadi et al.,, 2016), the term σ𝜎\sigma is lower bounded by

(9) σ≥c2​q​T​l​o​g​(1/δ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑞𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔1𝛿𝜀\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{q\sqrt{Tlog(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}

for item level DP. Extending the bound to group level DP, for groups of size k𝑘k, by substituting (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) with (k​ε,k​e(k−1)​ε​δ)𝑘𝜀𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿(k\varepsilon,ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta) gives us

σ≥c2​k​q​T​l​o​g​(k​e(k−1)​ε/kδ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑘𝑞𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝑘𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{kq\sqrt{Tlog(\frac{ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon/k}}{\delta})}}{\varepsilon}

We get the theorem’s inequality by substituting σ𝜎\sigma as above.

∎

Combining Lemma 4.7 with Theorem 4.6 gives us

Theorem 4.8.

The excess population loss of 𝒜\localgroupdpsubscript𝒜\localgroupdp\mathcal{A}_{\localgroupdp} is satisfied by

Δ​ℒ​(𝒜\localgroupdp;𝒟)≤Δℒsubscript𝒜\localgroupdp𝒟absent\displaystyle\Delta\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A}_{\localgroupdp};\mathcal{D})\leq
M22​η​T+η​L22+η​d​c22​k2​q2ε2​(T​l​o​g​k​e(k−1)​ε/kδ)superscript𝑀22𝜂𝑇𝜂superscript𝐿22𝜂𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22superscript𝑘2superscript𝑞2superscript𝜀2𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝑘𝛿\displaystyle\frac{M^{2}}{2\eta T}+\frac{\eta L^{2}}{2}+\eta d\frac{c_{2}^{2}k^{2}q^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\left(Tlog\frac{ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon/k}}{\delta}\right)
+L2​η​(T+1)nsuperscript𝐿2𝜂𝑇1𝑛\displaystyle+L^{2}\frac{\eta(T+1)}{n}

Note that the noise term amplifies quadratically with group size k𝑘k, which leads to rapid utility degradation with increasing group size. The excess population loss measure for UserLDP can be obtained by simply replacing the group size term k𝑘k to the size of the minibatch m𝑚m, which clearly leads to significantly greater noise amplification. Furthermore, by Theorem 3.10, the noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma is lower bounded by

σ≥c2​T​l​o​g​(1/δ)ε𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\sigma\geq c_{2}\frac{\sqrt{Tlog(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}

Recall the sampling probability escalates to q=1𝑞1q=1 for UserLDP. This leads to the following theorem

Theorem 4.9.

The excess population loss of 𝒜UserLDPsubscript𝒜UserLDP\mathcal{A}_{\emph{UserLDP}} is satisfied by

Δ​ℒ​(𝒜UserLDP;𝒟)≤Δℒsubscript𝒜UserLDP𝒟absent\displaystyle\Delta\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{A}_{\emph{UserLDP}};\mathcal{D})\leq
M22​η​T+η​L22+η​d​c22​m2ε2​(T​l​o​g​m​e(m−1)​ε/mδ)superscript𝑀22𝜂𝑇𝜂superscript𝐿22𝜂𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑐22superscript𝑚2superscript𝜀2𝑇𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑚superscript𝑒𝑚1𝜀𝑚𝛿\displaystyle\frac{M^{2}}{2\eta T}+\frac{\eta L^{2}}{2}+\eta d\frac{c_{2}^{2}m^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\left(Tlog\frac{me^{(m-1)\varepsilon/m}}{\delta}\right)
+L2​η​(T+1)nsuperscript𝐿2𝜂𝑇1𝑛\displaystyle+L^{2}\frac{\eta(T+1)}{n}

4.3. Utility Loss for \higradavg

Recall that unlike \localgroupdp, \higradavg does not scale up the noise to the group size of a subject in a minibatch. It instead scales down the gradients of all data items of the subject to a single data item’s gradient bounds (established by the clipping threshold). As a result, the noise amplification we showed for \localgroupdp does not exist for \higradavg. However, scaling down the gradient signal of a subject does indeed affect \higradavg’s utility. To show the effect formally we go back to the classic analysis of gradient descent for convex-Lipschitz functions, Lemma 14.114.114.1 in (Shalev-Shwartz & Ben-David,, 2014).

Let 𝐰∗=a​r​g​m​i​n𝐰∈W​ℒ^​(𝐰,S)superscript𝐰𝐰𝑊𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑚𝑖𝑛^ℒ𝐰𝑆{\bf w}^{*}=\underset{{\bf w}\in W}{argmin}~{}\hat{\mathcal{L}}({\bf w},S). Given that ℒ^^ℒ\hat{\mathcal{L}} is a convex L𝐿L-Lipschitz function, from (Shalev-Shwartz & Ben-David,, 2014) we have

The first term on the RHS of the inequality scales linearly with k𝑘k, the expected number of data items per subject. Thus we should expect some utility loss compared to DP-SGD for k>1𝑘1k>1. However, the second noise term, scales quadratically with k𝑘k, somewhat similar to that in \localgroupdp and UserLDP.

5. Empirical Evaluation

We implemented all our algorithms UserLDP, \localgroupdp, and \higradavg, and a version of the DP-SGD algorithm by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al.,, 2016) that enforces item level DP in the FL setting (LocalItemDP). We also compare these algorithms with a FL training algorithm, FedAvg (Konecný et al.,, 2015), that does not enforce any privacy guarantees. All our algorithms are implemented in our distributed FL framework built on distributed PyTorch.

We focus our evaluation on Cross-Silo FL (Kairouz et al.,, 2019), which we believe is the most appropriate setting for the subject level privacy problem. We use the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets (Caldas et al.,, 2018) for our evaluation. In FEMNIST, the hand-written numbers and letters can be divided based on authors, which ordinarily serve as federation users in FL experiments by most researchers. In Shakespeare, each character in the Shakespeare plays serves as a federation user. In our experiments however, the FEMNIST authors and Shakespeare play characters are treated as data subjects. To emulate the cross-silo FL setting, we report evaluation on a 16-user federation.

We use the CNN model on FEMNIST appearing in the LEAF benchmark suite (Caldas et al.,, 2018) as our target model to train. More specifically, the model consists of two convolution layers interleaved with ReLU activations and maxpooling, followed by two fully connected layers before a final log softmax layer. For the Shakespeare dataset we use a stacked LSTM model with two linear layers at the end.

We use 80%percent8080\% of the training data for training, and 20%percent2020\% for validation. Test data comes separately in FEMNIST and Shakespeare. Training and testing was done on a local GPU cluster comprising 222 nodes, each containing 888 Nvidia Tesla V100 GPUs.

We extensively tuned the hyperparameters of mini-batch size B𝐵B, number of training rounds T𝑇T, gradient clipping threshold C𝐶C, and learning rate η𝜂\eta. The final hyperparameters for FEMNIST were: B=512𝐵512B=512, T=100𝑇100T=100, C=0.001𝐶0.001C=0.001, and learning rates η𝜂\eta of 0.0010.0010.001 and 0.010.010.01 for the non-private and private FL algorithms respectively. Shakespeare hyperparameters were: B=100𝐵100B=100, T=200𝑇200T=200, C=0.00001𝐶0.00001C=0.00001, and learning rates η𝜂\eta of 0.00020.00020.0002 and 0.010.010.01 for the non-private and private FL algorithms.

In our implementations of all our algorithms UserLDP, \localgroupdp, and \higradavg, we used the privacy loss horizontal composition accounting technique that reduces the number of training rounds by s𝑠\sqrt{s}, where s𝑠s is the number of sampled users per training round. We experimented with the alternative approach that scales up the number of minibatches by s𝑠s to calculate a larger noise scale σ𝜎\sigma, but this approach consistently yielded worse model utility than our first approach. Hence here we report only the performance of our first approach.

5.1. FEMNIST and Shakespeare Performance

We first conduct an experiment that reports average test accuracy and loss at the end of each training round, over a total of 100100100 and 200200200 training rounds for FEMNIST and Shakespeare respectively. The FEMNIST dataset contains 350035003500 subjects, and the Shakespeare dataset contains 660660660 subjects. In FEMNIST, the average number of data items per subject is 145145145, whereas in case of Shakespeare it is 4,48444844,484. As we shall see later in this section, these subject cardinalities significantly contribute to performance of our algorithms’ models. Each subject’s data items are uniformly distributed among the 161616 federation users.

Figure 1 shows performance of the models trained using our algorithms. FedAvg performs the best since it does not incur any DP enforcement penalties. Item level privacy enforcement in LocalItemDP results in performance degradation of 8%percent88\% for FEMNIST and 22%percent2222\% for Shakespeare. The utility cost of user level LDP in UserLDP is quite clear from the figure. This cost is also reflected in the relatively high observed loss for the respective model. \localgroupdp performs significantly better than UserLDP, but worse than LocalItemDP, by 15%percent1515\% on FEMNIST, and 18%percent1818\% on Shakespeare. The reason for \localgroupdp’s worse performance is clear from Figure 2(a) and (c): the group size for a mini-batch tends to be dominated by 333 on both FEMNIST and Shakespeare, which cuts the privacy budget for these mini-batches by a factor of 333, leading to greater Gaussian noise, which in turn leads to model performance degradation.

\higradavg

performs worse than \localgroupdp because we need to use the sampling fraction of largest cardinality subjects at federation users when calculating mini-batch noise scale (Theorem 3.7). This amounts to noise scale amplification by approximately an order of magnitude. This amplification is much higher for Shakespeare (with an average of 4,48444844,484 data items per subject) by another order of magnitude, because of which \higradavg’s model’s utility is the worst. Moreover, privacy loss amplification due to horizontal composition limits the amount of training thereby further limiting model utility (in all our algorithms).

5.2. Effect of Subject Data Distribution

While evaluation of our algorithms using a uniform distribution of subject data among federation users is a good starting point, often times the data distribution is non-uniform in real world settings. To emulate varying subject data distributions, we conduct experiments on the FEMNIST dataset where subject data is distributed among federation users according to the power distribution

P​(x;α)=α​xα−1,0≤x≤1,α>0formulae-sequenceformulae-sequence𝑃𝑥𝛼𝛼superscript𝑥𝛼10𝑥1𝛼0\displaystyle P(x;\alpha)=\alpha x^{\alpha-1},0\leq x\leq 1,\alpha>0

Figure 3 shows performance of the models trained using our algorithms over varying subject data distributions of FEMNIST. As expected, different data distributions clearly do not significantly affect FedAvg, LocalItemDP, and User-Local-SGD. However, performance of the model trained using \localgroupdp degrades noticeably as the unevenness of data distribution increases, resulting in test accuracy under 50%percent5050\% for α=16𝛼16\alpha=16. This degradation is singularly attributable to growth in subject group size per mini-batch – the average group size per mini-batch ranges from 333 when α=2𝛼2\alpha=2 to 666 when α=16𝛼16\alpha=16. This increase in group size significantly reduces the privacy budget leading to increase in Gaussian noise that restricts test accuracy. On the other hand, though \higradavg’s model utility is much lower than that of \localgroupdp’s, it appears to be much more resilient to non-uniform subject data distributions among federation users up to α=8𝛼8\alpha=8, and therafter drops noticeably at α=16𝛼16\alpha=16.

6. Conclusion

While various prior works on privacy in FL have explored DP guarantees at the user and item levels (Liu et al.,, 2020; McMahan et al.,, 2018), to the best of our knowledge, no prior work has studied subject level granularity for privacy in the FL setting. In this paper, we presented a formal definition of subject level DP. We also presented three novel FL training algorithms that guarantee subject level DP by either enforcing user level LDP (UserLDP), local group DP (\localgroupdp), or by applying hierarchical gradient averaging to obfuscate a subject’s contribution to mini-batch gradients (\higradavg). Our formal analysis over convex loss functions shows that all our algorithms affect utility loss in interesting ways, with \localgroupdp incurring lower utility loss than UserLDP and \higradavg. Our empirical evaluation on the FEMNIST and Shakespeare datasets aligns with our formal analysis showing that while both UserLDP and \higradavg can significantly degrade model performance, \localgroupdp tends to incur much less loss in model performance compared to LocalItemDP, an algorithm that provides a weaker item level privacy guarantee. We also observe an interesting new aspect of horizontal composition of privacy loss for subject level privacy in FL that results in model performance degradation. Both our formal and empirical analysis demonstrate that there remains significant room for model utility improvements in algorithms that guarantee subject level DP in FL.

Appendix A Additional Proofs

The following theorem is a restatement of Theorem 3.2 and, in our notation, of Theorem 2.22.22.2 and the associated footnote 111 from Dwork and Roth (Dwork & Roth,, 2014, §2.3):

Theorem A.1.

Any (ε,δ𝜀𝛿\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒟→ℛ:𝒜→𝒟ℛ\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is (k​ε,k​e(k−1)​ε​δ𝑘𝜀𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿k\varepsilon,ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private for groups of size k≥2𝑘2k\geq 2. That is, for all D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} such that D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differ in at most k𝑘k data items, and for all S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R},

Pr​[𝒜​(D)∈S]Prdelimited-[]𝒜𝐷𝑆\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D)\in S] ≤\displaystyle\leq ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+ek​ε−1eε−1​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿\displaystyle e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+{\displaystyle{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}}\delta
≤\displaystyle\leq ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+k​e(k−1)​ε​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿\displaystyle e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta
<\displaystyle< ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+k​ek​ε​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀𝛿\displaystyle e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+ke^{k\varepsilon}\delta
Proof.

Suppose that D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differ in exactly k𝑘k data items. Choose any order for these items and call them d1,d2,…,dksubscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2…subscript𝑑𝑘d_{1},d_{2},\ldots,d_{k}. It follows that:

Pr​[𝒜​(D0)∈S]≤eε​Pr​[𝒜​(D1)∈S]+δ≤eε​(eε​Pr​[𝒜​(D2)∈S]+δ)+δ≤eε​(eε​(eε​Pr​[𝒜​(D3)∈S]+δ)+δ)+δ≤⋯≤eε​(eε​(eε​⋯​(eε​Pr​[𝒜​(Dk)∈S]+δ)​⋯+δ)+δ)+δ≤ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+(∑0≤i≤k−1ei​ε)​δ=ek​ε​Pr​[𝒜​(D′)∈S]+ek​ε−1eε−1​δPrdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷0𝑆missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷1𝑆𝛿missing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝜀superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷2𝑆𝛿𝛿missing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝜀superscript𝑒𝜀superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷3𝑆𝛿𝛿𝛿missing-subexpression⋯missing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝜀superscript𝑒𝜀superscript𝑒𝜀⋯superscript𝑒𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜subscript𝐷𝑘𝑆𝛿⋯𝛿𝛿𝛿missing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆subscript0𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑒𝑖𝜀𝛿missing-subexpressionsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀Prdelimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐷′𝑆superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿\begin{array}[]{lll}\hbox to0.0pt{$\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{0})\in S]$\hss\hss}\\ &\leq&e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{1})\in S]+\delta\\ &\leq&e^{\varepsilon}(e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{2})\in S]+\delta)+\delta\\ &\leq&e^{\varepsilon}(e^{\varepsilon}(e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{3})\in S]+\delta)+\delta)+\delta\\ &\leq&\cdots\\ &\leq&e^{\varepsilon}(e^{\varepsilon}(e^{\varepsilon}\cdots(e^{\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D_{k})\in S]+\delta)\cdots+\delta)+\delta)+\delta\\ &\leq&e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+{\displaystyle\left(\sum_{0\leq i\leq k-1}e^{i\varepsilon}\right)}\delta\\ &=&e^{k\varepsilon}\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in S]+{\displaystyle{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}}\delta\end{array}

This is the tightest possible bound using this proof technique (also presented as Lemma 111 in (Jagielski et al.,, 2020)). However, the expression ek​ε−1eε−1​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}\delta can be unwieldy for some purposes. Other authors (Dwork & Roth,, 2014; Vadhan,, 2017) state this theorem with a slightly larger value than necessary, perhaps for the sake of conciseness: because ei​ε≤e(k−1)​εsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝜀superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀e^{i\varepsilon}\leq e^{(k-1)\varepsilon} for any i≤k−1𝑖𝑘1i\leq k-1, (∑0≤i≤k−1ei​ε)​δ≤(∑0≤i≤k−1e(k−1)​ε)​δ=k​e(k−1)​ε​δsubscript0𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑒𝑖𝜀𝛿subscript0𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿\left(\sum_{0\leq i\leq k-1}e^{i\varepsilon}\right)\delta\leq\left(\sum_{0\leq i\leq k-1}e^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\right)\delta=ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta (Dwork & Roth,, 2014) (equality with ek​ε−1eε−1​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}\delta holds only when k=1𝑘1k=1). Sometimes k​e(k−1)​ε​δ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta is further simplified to k​ek​ε​δ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀𝛿ke^{k\varepsilon}\delta (Vadhan,, 2017), which is strictly larger for all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1.

Because all four of the expressions ek​εsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀e^{k\varepsilon}, ek​ε−1eε−1​δsuperscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}\delta, k​e(k−1)​ε​δ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta, and k​ek​ε​δ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀𝛿ke^{k\varepsilon}\delta decrease (strictly) monotonically as k𝑘k decreases, the same statements apply even if D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differ in fewer than k𝑘k data items. Thus one can say that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is either (k​ε,ek​ε−1eε−1​δ𝑘𝜀superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀1𝛿k\varepsilon,{e^{k\varepsilon}-1\over e^{\varepsilon}-1}\delta)-differentially private, (k​ε,k​e(k−1)​ε​δ𝑘𝜀𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘1𝜀𝛿k\varepsilon,ke^{(k-1)\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private, or even (k​ε,k​ek​ε​δ𝑘𝜀𝑘superscript𝑒𝑘𝜀𝛿k\varepsilon,ke^{k\varepsilon}\delta)-differentially private for groups of size k𝑘k; the first of these three statements is the tightest bound on the failure probability. ∎

Theorem A.2 (Same as Theorem 3.11).

UserLDP with parameter updates satisfying Equation 6 as observed by the federation server in a training round, enforces user level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-local differential privacy provided the noise parameter σ𝜎\sigma satisfies the inequality from Theorem 3.10, and the following inequality

σ>12​π​ε​δ​eε𝜎12𝜋𝜀𝛿superscript𝑒𝜀\displaystyle\sigma>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}\varepsilon\delta e^{\varepsilon}}
Proof.

Let O​(u1)𝑂subscript𝑢1O(u_{1}) and O​(u2)𝑂subscript𝑢2O(u_{2}) be the norms of the unperturbed outputs of a training round for users u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} respectively.

Assuming w.l.o.g. training for T𝑇T mini-batches per training round at u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2}, from Lemma 3.9 we get

O​(u1)≤η​T​C𝑂subscript𝑢1𝜂𝑇𝐶\displaystyle O(u_{1})\leq\eta TC
O​(u2)≤η​T​C𝑂subscript𝑢2𝜂𝑇𝐶\displaystyle O(u_{2})\leq\eta TC

Now the privacy loss random variable of interest is

|log𝒫[Fl(Du1]=s𝒫​[Fl​(Du2)]=s|=|loge​x​p​(−12​σ2​O​(u1)2)e​x​p​(−12​σ2​O​(u2)2)|\displaystyle\bigg{|}log\frac{\mathcal{P}[F_{l}(D_{u_{1}}]=s}{\mathcal{P}[F_{l}(D_{u_{2}})]=s}\bigg{|}=\bigg{\rvert}log\frac{exp(\frac{-1}{2\sigma^{2}}O(u_{1})^{2})}{exp(\frac{-1}{2\sigma^{2}}O(u_{2})^{2})}\bigg{\rvert}
=|logexp(−12​σ2(O(u2)2−O(u1)2))|\displaystyle=\bigg{\rvert}log\ exp(\frac{-1}{2\sigma^{2}}(O(u_{2})^{2}-O(u_{1})^{2}))\bigg{\rvert}
=12​σ2​|O​(u2)2−O​(u1)2|absent12superscript𝜎2𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢22𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢12\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}|O(u_{2})^{2}-O(u_{1})^{2}|

This quantity is upper bounded by ε𝜀\varepsilon if

|O​(u2)2−O​(u1)2|≤2​ε​σ2𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢22𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢122𝜀superscript𝜎2\displaystyle|O(u_{2})^{2}-O(u_{1})^{2}|\leq 2\varepsilon\sigma^{2}

𝒫​[|O​(u2)2−O​(u1)2|≥2​ε​σ2]<δ𝒫delimited-[]𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢22𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑢122𝜀superscript𝜎2𝛿\displaystyle\mathcal{P}[|O(u_{2})^{2}-O(u_{1})^{2}|\geq 2\varepsilon\sigma^{2}]<\delta

σ2​π​1t​e​x​p​(−t22​σ2)<δ2𝜎2𝜋1𝑡𝑒𝑥𝑝superscript𝑡22superscript𝜎2𝛿2\displaystyle\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\frac{1}{t}exp(\frac{-t^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}})<\frac{\delta}{2}

Theorem A.3 (Same as Theorem 3.12).

Given a FL training algorithm ℱ=(ℱl,ℱg)ℱsubscriptℱ𝑙subscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}), in the most general case where a subject’s data resides in the private datasets of multiple federation users uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, the aggregation algorithm ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} adaptively composes subject level privacy losses incurred by ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} at each federation user.

Proof.

Assume two distinct users u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} in a federation that host private data items of subject s𝑠s. Let ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1} and ε2subscript𝜀2\varepsilon_{2} be the respective subject privacy losses incurred by the two users during a training round.

It is straightforward to see that, in the worst case, data items of s𝑠s at users u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} can affect disjoint parameters in ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Thus parameter averaging done by ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} simply results in summation and scaling of these disjoint parameter updates. As a result, the privacy losses, ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1} and ε2subscript𝜀2\varepsilon_{2} incurred by u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} respectively are retained to their entirety by ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g}. In other words, privacy losses incurred for subject s𝑠s at users u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} compose adaptively. ∎

Theorem A.4 (Same as Theorem 3.13).

Consider a FL training algorithm ℱ=(ℱl,ℱg)ℱsubscriptℱ𝑙subscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}=(\mathcal{F}_{l},\mathcal{F}_{g}) that samples s𝑠s users per training round, and trains the model ℳℳ\mathcal{M} for R𝑅R rounds. Let ℱlsubscriptℱ𝑙\mathcal{F}_{l} at each participating user, over the aggregate of R𝑅R training rounds, locally enforce subject level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-DP. Then ℱℱ\mathcal{F} globally enforces the same subject level (ε𝜀\varepsilon,δ𝛿\delta)-DP guarantee by training for Rs𝑅𝑠\frac{R}{\sqrt{s}} rounds.

Proof.

The proof of training round constraints on horizontal composition can be broken down into two cases: First, each user in the federation locally trains for exactly T𝑇T mini-batches per training round, with exactly the same mini-batch sampling probability q𝑞q. Since horizontal composition is equivalent to adaptive composition in the worst case, the moments accountant method shows us that the resulting algorithm will be (O​(q​ε​T​R​s),δ)𝑂𝑞𝜀𝑇𝑅𝑠𝛿(O(q\varepsilon\sqrt{TRs}),\delta)-differentially private. To compensate for the s𝑠\sqrt{s} factor scaling of the privacy loss, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} can be executed for Rs𝑅𝑠\frac{R}{\sqrt{s}} training rounds, yielding a (O​(q​ε​T​R),δ)𝑂𝑞𝜀𝑇𝑅𝛿(O(q\varepsilon\sqrt{TR}),\delta)-differentially private algorithm.

In the second case, each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} may train for a unique number of mini-batches per training round, with a unique mini-batch sampling probability dictated by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}’s private dataset. Let T1,T2,…,Tssubscript𝑇1subscript𝑇2…subscript𝑇𝑠T_{1},T_{2},...,T_{s}, and q1,q2,…,qssubscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2…subscript𝑞𝑠q_{1},q_{2},...,q_{s} be the number of mini-batches per training round and mini-batch sampling fraction for the sampled users u1,u2,…,ussubscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2…subscript𝑢𝑠u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{s} respectively.

All our algorithms 3, 1, and 2 locally enforce subject level (O​(qi​ε​Ti​R)𝑂subscript𝑞𝑖𝜀subscript𝑇𝑖𝑅O(q_{i}\varepsilon\sqrt{T_{i}R}),δ𝛿\delta)-DP at each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. Privacy enforcement is done independently at each federation user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. Furthermore, note that the privacy loss is uniformly apportioned among training rounds. Let ℰ=O​(qi​ε​Ti​R)ℰ𝑂subscript𝑞𝑖𝜀subscript𝑇𝑖𝑅\mathcal{E}=O(q_{i}\varepsilon\sqrt{T_{i}R}). Note that ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is identical for each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} in the federation. Thus if ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is the total privacy loss budget over R𝑅R training rounds, a sampled user incurs εr=ℰ/Rsubscript𝜀𝑟ℰ𝑅\varepsilon_{r}=\mathcal{E}/R privacy loss in a single training round r𝑟r. Similarly, each of the s𝑠s sampled users in round r𝑟r incurs identical privacy loss εrsubscript𝜀𝑟\varepsilon_{r} despite having different mini-batches per training round Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} and mini-batch sampling probabilities qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}s. As noted earlier, these privacy losses compose horizontally (adaptively) via ℱgsubscriptℱ𝑔\mathcal{F}_{g} over s𝑠s users, leading to privacy loss amplification by a factor of s𝑠\sqrt{s} as per the moments accountant method. Given a fixed privacy loss budget ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, to compensate for this privacy loss amplification, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} can be executed for Rs𝑅𝑠\frac{R}{\sqrt{s}} training rounds. ∎
